# _Steatoda nobilis_

Jump to navigation Jump to search

_Steatoda nobilis_  
---  
[![Spider
2007-3.jpg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Spider_2007-3.jpg/250px-
Spider_2007-3.jpg)](/wiki/File:Spider_2007-3.jpg)

**_Steatoda nobilis_**  
([Thorell](/wiki/Tamerlan_Thorell "Tamerlan Thorell"), 1875)  
[![Distribution.steatoda.nobilis.1.png](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Distribution.steatoda.nobilis.1.png/250px-
Distribution.steatoda.nobilis.1.png)](/wiki/File:Distribution.steatoda.nobilis.1.png)  
  
_**Steatoda nobilis**_ is a [spider](/wiki/Spider "Spider") in the genus
_[Steatoda](/wiki/Steatoda "Steatoda")_ , known in the United Kingdom as the
**noble false widow**[1][2] and often referred to as the **false widow**.[a]
As the common name indicates, the spider superficially resembles and is
frequently confused for the black widow and other spiders in the genus
_[Latrodectus](/wiki/Latrodectus "Latrodectus")_ , which can have medically
significant venom. _Steatoda nobilis_ is native to [Madeira](/wiki/Madeira
"Madeira") and the [Canary Islands](/wiki/Canary_Islands "Canary Islands")
from where it allegedly spread to Europe,[3] and arrived in England before
1879, perhaps through cargo sent to [Torquay](/wiki/Torquay "Torquay").[4] In
England it has a reputation as one of the few local spider species which is
capable of inflicting a painful bite to humans,[5] with most bites resulting
in symptoms similar to a bee or wasp sting.[6] It has also been found in
[California](/wiki/California "California") and [Chile](/wiki/Chile "Chile").

  * 1 Description
  * 2 Distribution, habitat and ecology
    * 2.1 Population expansion in UK and Ireland
  * 3 Medical significance

##
Description[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Steatoda_nobilis&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Description")]

_Steatoda nobilis_ has a brown bulbous abdomen with cream coloured markings
that are often likened to the shape of a skull.[7] The legs are reddish-
orange.[8] Females range in size from about 9.5 to 14 mm in size, while males
are 7 to 11 mm.[1] Males are able to produce [stridulation](/wiki/Stridulation
"Stridulation") sounds during courtship[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_], by
scraping 10-12 teeth on the abdomen against a file on the rear of the
carapace.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Male2.jpg/220px-
Male2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Male2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Male2.jpg "Enlarge")

Male with swollen [pedipalps](/wiki/Pedipalp "Pedipalp")

## Distribution, habitat and
ecology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Steatoda_nobilis&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Distribution, habitat and ecology")]

The spider is an [introduced species](/wiki/Introduced_species "Introduced
species") across Europe, plus parts of North Africa, and likely spreading. It
was found for the first time in 2011 in [Cologne](/wiki/Cologne "Cologne"),
Germany.[9] It is originally from the [Canary Islands](/wiki/Canary_Islands
"Canary Islands") and [Madeira](/wiki/Madeira "Madeira").[10] In England it
has been reported mostly in southern counties,[11][12] but its range appears
to be expanding northwards.[13] In 2011, the spider was reported as an
established [invasive species](/wiki/Invasive_species "Invasive species") in
the USA, in [Ventura County, California](/wiki/Ventura_County,_California
"Ventura County, California").[14] In January 2016, it was reported that
_Steatoda nobilis_ had been found in [Chile](/wiki/Chile "Chile"), the first
time that the species had been recorded in the southern hemisphere.[15][16]

As with other members of the family [Theridiidae](/wiki/Theridiidae
"Theridiidae"), _Steatoda nobilis_ constructs a cobweb which is an irregular
tangle of sticky silken fibres. Its 'scaffold web' differs from others of the
genus in the exceptional strength of the silk, and in the tubular retreat that
is at least partly concealed in a deep crack or hole.[12] They have poor
eyesight and depend mostly on vibrations reaching them through their webs to
orient themselves to prey or warn them of larger animals that could injure or
kill them.

### Population expansion in UK and
Ireland[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Steatoda_nobilis&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Population expansion in UK and Ireland")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Steatoda_nobilis.jpg/220px-
Steatoda_nobilis.jpg)](/wiki/File:Steatoda_nobilis.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Steatoda_nobilis.jpg "Enlarge")

_Steatoda nobilis_ , Hampshire, England

The distribution of _Steatoda nobilis_ is expected to increase northwards in
the UK, due to, at least partly, mild winters in recent years. This prediction
was reported by Stuart Hine of the [Natural History
Museum](/wiki/Natural_History_Museum,_London "Natural History Museum,
London"),[17] and is substantiated by the National Recording Scheme.[12]

The spider is reported to be an established species in Ireland.[18]

## Medical
significance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Steatoda_nobilis&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Medical significance")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/SteatodaN.jpg/220px-
SteatodaN.jpg)](/wiki/File:SteatodaN.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:SteatodaN.jpg "Enlarge")

Female of _Steatoda nobilis_ in Hampshire

Like almost all spiders, _Steatoda nobilis_ is venomous, but its bite is
almost exclusively of mild effect on humans, without the severe consequences
that can occur with [black widow spiders](/wiki/Latrodectus_mactans
"Latrodectus mactans"). It is often alleged to be one of the spiders whose
bite involves venom [medically
significant](/wiki/List_of_medically_significant_spider_bites "List of
medically significant spider bites") for humans, even though the few recorded
bites do not typically present long-lasting effects. The symptoms of a bite
are typically similar to a bee or wasp sting.[8] The bite of this spider,
along with others in the genus _[Steatoda](/wiki/Steatoda "Steatoda")_ , can
produce a set of symptoms known as steatodism. Symptoms of bites include
intense pain radiating from the bite site, along with feverishness or general
malaise.[19] Male bites are less severe than those of females.[16]

## Media
reaction[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Steatoda_nobilis&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Media reaction")]

Sensationalised stories about the bite of _Steatoda nobilis_ have featured in
UK newspaper articles.[20][21] Stuart Hine from the [Natural History
Museum](/wiki/Natural_History_Museum,_London "Natural History Museum,
London"), London responded on the naturenet blog, stating, "Of course I also
explain the great value of spiders and how rare the event of spider bite in
the UK actually is. I also always explain that up to 12 people die from
wasp/bee stings in the UK each year and we do not panic so much about wasps
and bees â€“ but this never makes it past editing." [17] Steven Falk, an
[entomologist](/wiki/Entomology "Entomology"), cautioned that without "hard
evidence", it is difficult to know how many of the bites reported in the media
have been caused by false widow spiders.[22] The arrival of _Steatoda nobilis_
in Chile in 2016 led to a similar media reaction.[23]

### Alleged
incidents[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Steatoda_nobilis&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Alleged incidents")]

  * In 2006 a [Dorchester](/wiki/Dorchester,_Dorset "Dorchester, Dorset") man spent three days in [Dorset County Hospital](/wiki/Dorset_County_Hospital "Dorset County Hospital") with symptoms of heart seizure, after suffering a spider bite believed to be caused by _Steatoda nobilis_.[5]
  * In 2013 a man in [Sidcup](/wiki/Sidcup "Sidcup"), [Kent](/wiki/Kent "Kent") was allegedly bitten in his sleep, reporting that his hand had turned black and yellow. His hand remained swollen for five weeks until doctors gave him a course of antibiotics.[24]
  * In October 2013, it was reported that a man from [Romford](/wiki/Romford "Romford") in [Essex](/wiki/Essex "Essex") had been allegedly bitten by a false widow. He was treated for bacterial infection with [antibiotics](/wiki/Antibacterial "Antibacterial") and needed to have his leg drained of [pus](/wiki/Pus "Pus").[25]
  * In October 2013, a British school in the [Forest of Dean](/wiki/Forest_of_Dean "Forest of Dean") was closed for a day for [fumigation](/wiki/Fumigation "Fumigation") as a result of a dense population of _Steatoda nobilis_ on the site.[26]
  * In 2014, a woman from [County Durham](/wiki/County_Durham "County Durham") had her left index finger amputated after contracting the flesh-eating bug [necrotising fasciitis](/wiki/Necrotising_fasciitis "Necrotising fasciitis") following a claimed bite from a false widow spider.[27][28]
  * In October 2014, an Irish man went into [cardiac arrest](/wiki/Cardiac_arrest "Cardiac arrest") and spent a day in intensive care after being bitten three times by what was claimed as a false widow, on the hip, side and shoulder.[29]

## Notes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Steatoda_nobilis&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Notes")]

**a.** **^** The correct and full English name for _Steatoda nobilis_ is
"Noble false widow". Media coverage usually abbreviates this to "false widow",
although _Steatoda nobilis_ is strictly speaking one of the false widows.
_[Steatoda grossa](/wiki/Steatoda_grossa "Steatoda grossa")_[30] and
_[Steatoda paykulliana](/wiki/Steatoda "Steatoda")_[31] are other examples of
false widow spiders.
